channel.title: SuperScienceGrl
channel.description: Nessa Carson is a professional synthetic organic chemist working in HTE automation for pharma, and a freelance science writer and editor.

item.title: SuperScienceGrl is 3!
item.description:
SuperScienceGrl is 3 years old (tomorrow)! I can't honestly remember how it looked when it was launched.

But it's been fun, it taught me CSS and JavaScript right from the start, and since then I've started using Python to update some parts programmatically. Looks like I'm still learning from it, as today I took some time to learn about Sass, and switch my CSS over to Sass to make it more readable and updatable.

  • I've pushed a homepage update. I was never quite sure what to do with the homepage, until now when I've tied it in more with the popular style of personal website at the moment. I plan on adding more sections. I've not advertised it widely because it has my face on it. But there it is
  • The online chemistry calendar is now over, having featured 1244 webinars, conferences, and training courses (Apr–Sep 2020). It led out its full intended run up to Sep 2020, and its functionality and remaining content has now been ported over to https://researchseminars.org/, which is a global, crowdsourced site, run by MIT academics
  • As mentioned, I switched all my CSS over to .scss files with Sass. If I did it right, you won't see a change from this (apart from one very slight colour change to make things harmonious)

item.title: Who is really a scientist, anyway?
item.guid:
https://supersciencegrl.co.uk/pages/Who-is-a-scientist.html?rss=37 Sat, 24 Aug 2019 10:00:00 GMT http://supersciencegrl.co.uk/img/Mad_scientist.png Who is really a scientist? https://supersciencegrl.co.uk/pages/Who-is-a-scientist.html?rss=37

My new Chemistry World article, is up, asking: "who is a scientist, anyway?"

Whether in a lab, an office or on a stage, we are no strangers to wrestling with self-identity. Citizen scientists can build their confidence by engaging with real, scientific research, starting to feel that science is ‘for them’. However, this is still one of the factors that new researchers struggle with most.

item.title: Major June website update!
item.description:
I've been busy with starting my new job, so no update for a while means that this is a major one. I've been doing the following:

  • Updated the About page to reflect said new job
  • Added a link to my new, interactive, highlightable periodic table. I use it to keep a checklist of all the elements I've used during my time as a chemist, and now you can too!
  • Added the ability to automatically search from the Google Chrome Omnibox using the Chemical Vendor Search tools to the CVS and CVS USA pages
  • Added η and κ to the Character Map, after I myself needed them for compound names this week and found them absent. Now it's more inclusive of inorganickers…
  • Back end: updated the contact email encryption so it works better in 2019... sigh

Thanks for keeping up to date with my website. It's good fun and it keeps me learning.

Here's my new Chemistry World article Making A Meme Of It.

item.title: Bank holiday update
item.description: This is something I've been wanting to do for a while. Student and academic/postdoc options are now available on the Conference Database. item.title: Are You Reading Me?
item.description:
Here's my new article Are You Reading Me?, about life's constant struggle to keep up with the literature. It can be a challenge and a joy, but everyone needs a strategy to keep up with interesting papers.

A year ago, I decided to keep track of all the papers I read over the course of one week. ‘Read’ here, for the most part, actually means skimmed. Although for intense papers, deep...

item.title: New conferences
item.description:
It's all about efficiency - it's time for labs to get with the project plan and fail fast. Read the rest of my articles in Chemistry World here.

I was in a brilliant seminar by an American academic recently, and wondered how his group screened just so many conditions for its latest clever transformation. Questioning him later, I received the answer I half expected: a veritable army of postdocs...
